title: 106_hr2382
content: The "Child Abuse Reform and Enforcement Act of 1999" or "CARE Act of 1999" is the short title of the Act. Title I focuses on the withholding and redistribution of certain state child protection funds, specifically addressing the withholding and redistribution of state funds. The "Child Abuse Reform and Enforcement Act of 1999" mandates a 25 percent reduction in funding for states under the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act and the National Child Protection Act if they fail to meet the requirements outlined in the Act. Funds withheld will be redistributed to states that comply with the Act. A grant under title II of the Act can be used for computerizing data and criminal history files, improving existing data and files, and assisting states in transmitting data to national systems. Authorization of $50,000,000 for grants to improve child abuse crime information from 2000 to 2003. Requirement to equalize sentencing for intrafamilial and extrafamilial child sexual abuse. State Study of Laws Regarding Intrafamilial and Extrafamilial Child Sexual Abuse requires states to study and examine laws related to intrafamilial and extrafamilial child sexual abuse, including disparities in charging and sentencing perpetrators. The State must report study results on child sexual abuse to the Attorney General and implement legislative actions to equalize charging and sentencing for perpetrators, regardless of familial relationship to the victim. The Attorney General may extend the 1-year time requirement for a State if legislation is needed to meet the additional requirements of the Act, excluding funding legislation. State requirements for gathering information on sexual abuse of children include compiling and analyzing data on intrafamilial and extrafamilial abuse, promoting regulations for data collection by State courts and agencies, and submitting an annual report to specified entities.
